body: Thanks @ankitsinghal  and @chrajeshbabu. I have some more changes staged locally, too. Will update what I have (along with some "noop" implementations to show an e2e example) with your feedback!
LogName is kind of artificial thing. We should adopt standard Unix convention - everything is a file, Path in our case.  java.io.Path gives us direct way to LogService file system.

> We should adopt standard Unix convention - everything is a file, Path in our case. java.io.Path gives us direct way to LogService file system.

Good point. That makes sense.

Breaking this out to a top-level thread instead of being anchored on a code segment:

> We are not talking about full fledged FileSystem API here, but some API would help in adoption, taking into account familiar file system abstraction.

I had a chat with Ankit and Sergey about this one, trying to weigh the pros and cons. A FileSystem-like API would give users some familiarity in working with the LogService, but the general feeling was that we may be over-burdening ourselves in the first implementation. There would be many things we could potentially implement via a FileSystem like API which we wouldn't necessarily need for HBase as an initial consumer.

I think we could explore using a FileSystem-like API in the future to supplement a more minimal core API (closer to what is here already). Something higher-level could also be done as we get closer to HBase's rearchitecting.

I think it's becoming pretty clear that HBase's new WAL API won't be written using the notion of a File on a FileSystem (and instead use a "stream-like" API at the core). I could see us integrating the Ratis LogService into HBase via a FileSystem facade.

How do you feel about that, @VladRodionov? Are there any immediate concerns which would limit how we're thinking about building out the LogService if we didn't have a FileSystem facade?

Hmm, read, write, create, open, seek, close, sync, list, delete etc. What else? Is not this already File I/O? They are not streams as long as you provide positional access. They are files. In any case you will need API, which closely matches File I/O.
Dropped a big update that tries to account for the implementation decisions.

Rebased on master, updated javadoc, added a factory for LogService creation, and fixed a couple of other trivial cleanup things.

Good for a first draft, @VladRodionov @chrajeshbabu ?
I think this is close. @mukul1987 @szetszwo @anuengineer any input from y'all? Maybe a merge if you think this is OK :)

Overall looks good for the first cut. Just one question and one concern:

Q: May be I missed that, but I did not find truncate log method. The only way to say to Log Service that we do need anymore records with ID <= X. 
C: Still think that adopting hierarchical naming scheme for log directory is a right thing.

> Q: May be I missed that, but I did not find truncate log method. The only way to say to Log Service that we do need anymore records with ID <= X.

Nope, you're right. The API only lets you archive (or delete) an entire LogStream. I think this flows a bit more naturally with what we're doing inside of HBase already. We _could_ support intra-LogStream truncation and archival, but I think that would complicate things quite a lot.

>  C: Still think that adopting hierarchical naming scheme for log directory is a right thing.

Let's keep this in mind as we work on the LogStream administrative/management side. I think some hierarchy would make sense -- the notion of a namespace to separate different LogStreams using the same "storage directory" would be nice (DistributedLog has this concept).

Right now we just have a String (inside of `LogName`) to uniquely identify one LogStream from another. This was intentional to let us either change how `LogName`s compute uniqueness, or overlay some "logical" hierarchy using that arbitrary String.
This seems critical. Can you add a UT if possible? Thanks,
sounds like it has been resolved. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/RATIS-311
@chrajeshbabu @vladrodionov can you take a look for me? :)

Let me try to explain how this works now:

Take a "log" of data that looks like this:
```
["a", "b", "c", "d", "e"]
```

But, our Raft log may look like this:
```
[ config-entry, "a", ["b", "c", "d", "e"], config-entry]
```

The 3rd element in the above (`["b", "c", "d", "e"]`) would be created by the API call for `LogWriter#write(List<ByteBuffer)`. I think it is the LogStateMachine's job to unwrap this "complicated" physical representation and make the last example "appear" to be the first via the LogService API.

Let me know if this doesn't make sense. I want to also capture this in docs somewhere..
One more, @vladrodionov and @chrajeshbabu
It's looking good @joshelser .
+1 @joshelser .
You probably have some minor issue (see my comment inline in files changed), otherwise is looking good, @joshelser
+1 @joshelser
Thanks guys!
Hrm, this problem might be easier than I thought. Just noticed that I'm not always incrementing `raftLogIndex` which means the `while` loop would just spin fast.
a39eeb7 has a fix for the log reading and passes the current UTs (also, rebased on master)
Closed as this was submitted already.
Test failure was on `TestRaftWithSimulatedRpc.testWithLoad` which looks unrelated. I intend to push this today if there is no comment.

@szetszwo Finally I am ready to give it a try. You mentioned some logic here:
`SegmentedRaftLog#syncWithSnapshot`. I was wondering if my approach was the right direction.
Thanks @andy2git ,  I am reviewing your patch.  Sorry that I missed this pull request earlier.
Thanks @szetszwo! Addressed code review comments.
merged in 9dcb75a94eacae49b4fed7f7105b97deee4aba51. Close this request.

After RATIS-336 and RATIS-337, this is fixed by enforcing using Optional.

Thanks @dongeforever  for reporting this bug. Really appreciate it!

Not sure if it is an issue or just a normal logging, but anyways doesn't seem to be related to changes or JIRAs fixed under this pull request

```2019-05-02 03:22:56,201 WARN server.GrpcServerProtocolService (LogUtils.java:warn(136)) - worker2.logservice.ratis.org_9999: Failed requestVote worker1.logservice.ratis.org_9999->worker2.logservice.ratis.org_9999#0
org.apache.ratis.protocol.GroupMismatchException: worker2.logservice.ratis.org_9999: group-87E0933ED47B not found.
```

Yeah, I've seen this too, but I don't know what group this is actually referring to. Something else to dig into. I was ignoring it for now.

```
SEVERE: ~* Channel ManagedChannelImpl{logId=22, target=worker3.logservice.ratis.org:9999} was not shutdown properly!!! *~
Make sure to call shutdown()/shutdownNow() and wait until awaitTermination() returns true.
```

I'm guessing something around gRPC in the Ratis client code isn't closing stuff correctly in all situations. Another thing to come back to as it doesn't seem to be an immediate problem :)

I've seen both of these since doing stuff in the LogService. I don't think they're new.
Rebased the branch. 538ef5e has some basic validation to make sure we *don't* have `autoSnapshotEnabled`
The refactor and new docker scripts for docker handling are good @joshelser.
Thanks for looking, Rajeshbabu!
Looks good to me @joshelser. +1

Thanks for the update, Ankit! Looks like this needs a rebase, but, other than the docs pending, seems ready to go :)

I assume you've tried this out with one of the examples or the logservice to see the metrics reported over JMX?

Thanks a lot @joshelser  for the review. 

bq. I assume you've tried this out with one of the examples or the logservice to see the metrics reported over JMX?
Yes I have tested ratis core metrics in logservice as well and I can see them in JMX under Ratis domain and LogService metrics under RatisLogService domain.

> Yes I have tested ratis core metrics in logservice as well and I can see them in JMX under Ratis domain and LogService metrics under RatisLogService domain.

Perfect. Thanks!

Looks like precommit had some troubles with the unit tests (was worried that metrics were introducing some failures) but things still run fine locally. Let me merge this in.
cc: @lokeshj1703 / @mukul1987
Hey @elek, any feedback on these website changes? I see you've done most of the work so far to the site :)

Thanks Marton!

I'll tweak it a little bit with your suggestions. Appreciate your eyes on it.
Rebase'ed and merged this in after Nicholas' feedback. Thanks! Much nicer to use `build.sh` now.

Can confirm that the graphite wiring up works!
![Screen Shot 2019-06-25 at 6 50 27 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/67863/60139058-7d917600-977a-11e9-8465-12b92c665275.png)

One thing that looks curious is that we only ever have one metric per raft group. I would expect to see the full set of metrics for every group. This makes me think that something is de-duplicating them based on the final component of the metric name.

For example, instead of having sizeRequestTime_min for every "group_*", we only have one instance in "group_1C0AE431061C". I'm not sure if this is a bug in the Ratis metrics work or in the Reporter.

> This makes me think that something is de-duplicating them based on the final component of the metric name.

Reading through the metrics adapter again, I'm reminded that it's just tracking HashMaps of "name" to metric object (e.g. timer, counter, histogram).

IIRC, the nice hierarchy you have here in the metrics breakdown is via some magic prefix in the name itself (at least, JMX worked this way). Maybe the final name being exported from Ratis is identical, regardless of the RAFT Group (logservice "log") that the LogServer is operating on? That seems plausible given what else I'm seeing..

I dunno, now I'm confused. After letting it run for a bit, I'm seeing more metrics for every Group, but still not every metric. I'm not sure if it's working as intended (just with some delay) or if there is a problem here.
Trying this one out again locally. Is 4d6d1b3 unrelated cleanup, or does it help with the metrics seeming to take a while to show up?

Was chatting with @cbaenziger about this one. He said that he had seen some weirdness with Graphite before and made the suggestion to dump metrics to a file, instead, to make sure things are kosher.

Ah, d'oh. I didn't realize this was `hugo` under the hood -- and with its need for images to be in the `static` directory. Also I see GitHub and Hugo render Markdown differently w.r.t. the `img` tag. Thanks for heads-up about `hugo serve` for the future!
Thanks! LGTM and works on my test with `hugo serve`. BTW should I add the `dot` command to the `build.sh`?
+1, the Jenkins did run and looks like one test failed which does not look related.

> BTW should I add the dot command to the build.sh

Oh, that's not a bad idea (if the command exists). Let me try to add that.

> Let me try to add that.

Not super feasible because it will clobber the ASF license header. I don't see an obvious way to re-add the license via the DOT file itself, so I'm just skipping that part.

But, there is some good improvements coming into `build.sh` as a result of me messing around here.
Can you take a look again, @cbaenziger ?
OK, 261e8a1 can regenerate the license header on OSX. Let me test on Linux too.

15ca39f fixes the issue of building on Linux. Going to squash/rebase this one as I think this will be good for what you were looking for :)

If the user doesn't have `dot` on the `$PATH`, we won't re-generate the SVG and everything else should continue as expected.
Merged!
